   Imaging: CT chest- non-con:
   Large bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis.
   Additional multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally suggest
   infection. Limited assessment for small airways disease given
   respiratory motion. Underlying moderate emphysema at the lung apices.
   Atherosclerotic disease. Comparison to prior OSH images will be useful,
   please have these uploaded to [**Hospital1 19**] PACS
   system.
   Microbiology: Legionella urinary Ag (-)
   Assessment and Plan:  83M with sCHF (EF 40%), presenting from OSH with
   acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP, unexplained
   hemoptysis and acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes BOOP, CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, and VAP.  No evidence of emphasematous changes on recent
   imaging to suggest obstructive physiology.
   - will upload outside hospital imaging
   - will wean steroids
   - will convert to meropenem for Klebsiella in sputum, repeat sputum cx,
   follow up sensitivies
   - see below for CHF management
   .
   # Question BOOP/COP: Patient with symptoms of dyspnea, hemoptysis.
   Evidence on CT noted above in history. Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA
   were noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  The patient is now
   s/p  days of 0.5 gm of Solumedrol. Patients last PFTs were noted to be
   consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   - Upload CT Chest into records -> f/u in PACS
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   - begin steroid wean to once daily methylprednisolone
   - will repeat ANCA, [**Doctor First Name **], anti-GBM
   .
   #. Chronic Systolic CHF: Pt with last known EF of 40%. Now appears to
   be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion.
   Diuresis unsuccessful yesterday, per report, now appears to be
   improving according to physician at OSH.
   - repeat TTE this morning
   - will place on lasix gtt this morning, goal (-) 2 to 2.5 liters today
   - favor optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction -> will start
   isosorbide mononitrate, avoid ACEi given tenuous renal fxn, B blockade
   given 1^st degree AV block
   .
   # CAD s/p angioplasty, stent x 1:  troponin elevated, CK and MB
   normal.  Given recent history of hemoptysis and possible RML
   hemorrhage, renal insufficiency, and no significant ECG changes from
   admission to OSH, will defer anti-platelet and anti-coagulation at this
   time.  Will continue to trend and continue ASA 325 mg daily
   - hold statin in setting of transaminitis
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: DDx includes prerenal azotemia (poor
   forward flow, intravascular depletion), intrinsic, post-renal. Although
   now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.  No signs of acidosis,
   hyperkalemia to sugest urgent emergeny need for dialysis. Pt may
   require HD vs CVVH given azotemia.  Steroid-induced catabolic state
   likely etiology of elevated BUN.
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   - UA with sediment and cx
   - Urine Lytes
   - f/u Renal recs, appreciate recs
   .
   #.  Hypernatremia- suspect intravascular volume depletion in setting of
   recent diuresis and elevated BUN, serum osmolality.
   -  will correct free water deficit with D5W, 1.7 liters to correct to
   148 in next 8 hours
   -  serial Na
   .
   #.  Type II DM- on SSI, consider insulin gtt in morning.
   .
   FEN: no IVF
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .
   Full Code
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, unexplained hemoptysis, and acute on chronic kidney injury. He has a history of chronic systolic heart failure (EF 40%), coronary artery disease with stenting, and type II diabetes. The patient is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. He has a history of bilateral pleural effusions and peribronchial opacities on chest computed tomography (CT), which suggests infection. The patient is also receiving antibiotics for Klebsiella pneumonia, and steroids for bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to his prolonged intubation and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions and peribronchial opacities.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's CT scan shows multifocal peribronchial opacities, which may indicate pneumonia.
3. Heart failure: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, and his current condition may worsen his heart failure.
4. Chronic kidney injury: The patient has a history of chronic kidney injury, and his current condition may worsen his kidney function.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has a high serum sodium level, which may indicate intravascular volume depletion.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient has type II diabetes and is at risk of developing hypoglycemia, especially with the use of insulin.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his underlying conditions are not properly managed.
9. Sepsis: The patient's infection may progress to sepsis if not properly managed.
10. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to experience bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage his heart failure with diuretics and afterload reduction.
3. Continue to monitor his kidney function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
4. Continue to manage his diabetes with insulin and monitor his blood glucose levels.
5. Continue to monitor his electrolyte levels and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
6. Consider adding antibiotics to his treatment regimen if his infection does not improve with current therapy.
7. Consider adding anticoagulation therapy to his treatment regimen if his risk of thrombosis is high.
8. Consider adding a proton pump inhibitor to his treatment regimen to reduce his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Consider adding a stress ulcer prophylaxis to his treatment regimen to reduce his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust his treatment regimen as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, BOOP, unexplained hemoptysis, and acute on chronic kidney injury.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 82 bpm
* Blood pressure: 145/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 9 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, CAD with angioplasty and stenting, and type II diabetes.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and PEEP of 8 cmH2O. The patient is also receiving fentanyl for pain management.

The patient has a free water deficit, which is being repleted with D5W. The patient's sodium level is elevated, and the plan is to correct this with D5W.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 20.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 138 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.56 ng/mL
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* LDH: 443 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 3.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.7 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show large bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis and multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally, suggesting infection.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure
* BOOP/COP
* Chronic systolic heart failure
* Acute on chronic kidney injury
* Hypernatremia
* Type II diabetes

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning steroids for BOOP/COP
* Converting to meropenem for Klebsiella in sputum
* Repeating sputum culture and sensitivities
* Optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction
* Holding statin due to transaminitis
* Avoiding nephrotoxins and considering dialysis
* Correcting free water deficit with D5W
* Considering insulin gtt in morning

The patient's disposition is pending and will be determined based on the above plan and further evaluation.

Summary:

The patient is a 105.5 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, respiratory failure, and sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is receiving anticoagulation therapy. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 145/61 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 9 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient has a Foley catheter in place and is receiving fluid therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of hypernatremia, acute renal failure, and severe sepsis. His blood cultures are pending, and he is receiving antibiotics for suspected MRSA infection. The patient's imaging studies show large bilateral pleural effusions and multifocal peribronchial opacities, consistent with infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if the underlying infection is not effectively treated, or if the patient develops further complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock, which can lead to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed, leading to further fluid accumulation and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential complications such as seizures or coma.
5. Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other parts of the body, leading to further complications such as pneumonia, endocarditis, or meningitis.
6. Organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis and acute renal failure may lead to organ dysfunction, including cardiac, hepatic, or gastrointestinal dysfunction.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed, leading to delirium and potential complications such as falls or self-extubation.
8. Line-related complications: The patient's lines, including the PICC line and arterial line, may become infected or occluded, leading to further complications such as sepsis or tissue necrosis.
9. Pressure ulcer: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase the risk of pressure ulcer development.
10. DVT: The patient's immobility and underlying medical conditions may increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:  83M with sCHF (EF 40%), presenting from OSH with
   acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP, unexplained
   hemoptysis and acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes BOOP, CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, and VAP.  No evidence of emphasematous changes on recent
   imaging to suggest obstructive physiology.
   - will upload outside hospital imaging
   - consider a-line
   - consider restarting solumedrol in morning
   - cont zosyn for reported Klebsiella in sputum, repeat sputum cx
   .
   # Question BOOP/COP: Patient with symptoms of dyspnea, hemoptysis.
   Evidence on CT noted above.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were
   noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  The patient is now s/p
   days of 0.5, gm of Solumedrol. Patients last PFTs were noted to be
   consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   - Upload CT Chest into records
   - will consider cyclophosphamide
   - obtain path specimen for additional path review
   .
   # CAD s/p angioplasty, stent x 1:  troponin elevated, CK and MB
   normal.  Given recent history of hemoptysis and possible RML
   hemorrhage, renal insufficiency, and no significant ECG changes from
   admission to OSH, will defer anti-platelet and anti-coagulation at this
   time.  Will continue to trend and continue ASA 325 mg daily
   - hold statin in setting of transaminitis
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Pt underwent transbronichial biopsy at OSH.
   - follow-up OSH [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: DDx includes prerenal azotemia (poor
   forward flow, intravascular depletion), intrinsic, post-renal. Although
   now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.  No signs of acidosis,
   hyperkalemia to sugest urgent emergeny need for dialysis. Pt may
   require HD vs CVVH given azotemia.
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   - Stict I/Os
   - TTE
   - UA with sediment and cx
   - Urine Lytes
   - Likely renal c/s in morning
   .
   #. Chronic Systolic CHF: Pt with last known EF of 40%. Now appears to
   be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion.
   Diuresis unsuccessful yesterday, per report, now appears to be
   improving according to physician at OSH.
   - TTE
   - favor optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction
   .
   #.  Hypernatremia- suspect intravascular volume depletion in setting of
   recent diuresis and elevated BUN, serum osmolality.
   -  will correct free water deficit with D5W, 1.7 liters to correct to
   148 in next 8 hours
   -  serial Na
   .
   #.  Type II DM- on SSI, consider insulin gtt in morning.
   .
   FEN: no IVF
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .
   Full Code
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .

**Patient Information**

* Age: 83
* Sex: Male
* Admission diagnosis: Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure, BOOP, and Chronic Systolic CHF

**24-Hour Events**

* Invasive ventilation started on January 21, 2139, at 05:30 PM
* PICC line started on January 21, 2139, at 06:24 PM
* Nasal swab for MRSA taken on January 21, 2139, at 09:00 PM
* EKG taken on January 21, 2139, at 09:47 PM
* Urine culture taken on January 21, 2139, at 09:50 PM
* Blood cultured on January 22, 2139, at 12:49 AM and 01:16 AM

**Lab Results**

* WBC: 20.8-24.1
* Hct: 27.5-26.8
* Plt: 138-117
* Cr: 2.2-2.0
* TropT: 0.56-0.55
* TCO2: 28-29
* Glucose: 248-191
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Differential-Neuts, Albumin, LDH, Ca++, Mg++, PO4

**Imaging**

* CT chest: Large bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis, multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally suggesting infection, and underlying moderate emphysema at the lung apices

**Assessment and Plan**

* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Renal failure, acute (acute kidney injury)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)

**Recommendations**

* Increase FiO2 to 50%
* Consider a-line and restarting solumedrol in the morning
* Continue zosyn for reported Klebsiella in sputum, repeat sputum cx
* Upload outside hospital imaging
* Consider cyclophosphamide
* Obtain path specimen for additional path review
* Hold statin in setting of transaminitis
* Avoid nephrotoxins
* Strict I/Os
* TTE
* UA with sediment and cx
* Urine Lytes
* Likely renal c/s in the morning
* Favor optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction
* Correct free water deficit with D5W
* Serial Na
* Consider insulin gtt in the morning

**Potential Medical Complications**

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Renal failure
* Hypernatremia
* Type II DM
* Chronic Systolic CHF
* BOOP/COP
* Hemoptysis
* Acute on chronic kidney injury
* DVT
* Stress ulcer
* VAP

**Code Status**

* Full code

**Disposition**

* [Hospital Unit Name 1] pending above

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic systolic heart failure (EF 40%), chronic kidney injury, and a history of coronary artery disease with stenting. He is currently admitted to the ICU due to acute hypoxemic respiratory failure with evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), unexplained hemoptysis, and acute on chronic kidney injury.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure of 145/61 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 9 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on 40% FiO2, and his arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.52, PCO2 of 34 mmHg, and PO2 of 105 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, CK-MB, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating possible cardiac damage and inflammation. His complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 20.8 x 10^9/L, and his electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a sodium level of 152 mmol/L and a potassium level of 4.0 mmol/L.

The patient's chest computed tomography (CT) scan shows large bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis, multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally, and underlying moderate emphysema at the lung apices. His echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%.

The patient's medical management includes invasive ventilation, vasopressors, and diuretics. He is also receiving antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). His steroid dose is being weaned, and he is being treated for acute on chronic kidney injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's chest CT scan shows multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally, which could indicate pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure could worsen, leading to respiratory arrest.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure and elevated troponin-T levels could lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or heart failure exacerbation.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic kidney injury could worsen, leading to renal failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and inflammatory markers could indicate sepsis.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of chronic kidney injury and elevated LDH levels could increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and multiple comorbidities make him at high risk for various complications. Close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient, a 83-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic systolic heart failure. He is intubated and sedated, with a goal of diuresis. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 171/75 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 31 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97%.

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic systolic heart failure, and chronic kidney injury. He has also been diagnosed with bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypernatremia and hypokalemia.

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE), show evidence of left ventricular enlargement, moderate pulmonary edema, and moderate nonhemorrhagic bilateral pleural effusions. The TTE also shows mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with moderate global left ventricular hypokinesis.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued diuresis with furosemide, insulin drip, and mechanical ventilation. He will also receive prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer. The patient's code status is full code.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure may progress to respiratory failure, requiring increased mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic kidney injury may progress to acute renal failure, requiring dialysis.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to central nervous system (CNS) complications, such as seizures or coma.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state may increase his risk of infection, particularly with opportunistic pathogens.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's chronic kidney injury and diuretic therapy may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's coronary artery disease and chronic systolic heart failure may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuresis with furosemide to manage the patient's fluid overload.
2. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and correct any abnormalities.
3. Consider dialysis for the patient's acute on chronic kidney injury.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his mechanical ventilation as needed.
5. Consider antibiotics for the patient's suspected BOOP.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
7. Consider a gastroprotective agent to reduce the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 105.5 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and sedated, and has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, type II diabetes, and peripheral vascular disease.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 171/75 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 97% on a FiO2 of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 20.8 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, and a platelet count of 138 x 10^9/L. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.2 mmol/L, a sodium level of 150 mmol/L, and a chloride level of 111 mmol/L.

The patient's imaging studies show left ventricular enlargement, moderate pulmonary edema, and moderate nonhemorrhagic bilateral pleural effusions, consistent with chronic heart failure. The patient also has a small right middle lobe hematoma and severe atherosclerosis involving the coronaries, proximal head and neck, and abdominal arteries.

The patient's ICU care plan includes mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and management of hypernatremia. The patient is also receiving nutrition through a NovaSource Renal (Full) infusion at a rate of 40 mL/hour, and is being monitored for signs of sepsis and multiorgan dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient may still be at risk for respiratory failure due to chronic heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of chronic heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which may increase the risk of sepsis.
3. Multiorgan dysfunction: The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and chronic kidney disease, which may increase the risk of multiorgan dysfunction.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 150 mmol/L, which is above the normal range. Hypernatremia can lead to symptoms such as headache, nausea, and vomiting.
5. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is 4.2 mmol/L, which is below the normal range. Hypokalemia can lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 7.8 g/dL, which is below the normal range. Anemia can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
7. Chronic kidney disease: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease, which may increase the risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease progression.
8. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease, which may increase the risk of limb ischemia and gangrene.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   OSH with acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and
   acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome,
   VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).
   Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to moderate
   restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were
   noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart
   failure, as evidence by TTE, likely primary component.
   - son to attempt to obtain non-cont CT chest done prior to [**2139-1-5**]
   bronch
   - will cont to wean methylpred to 40 mg daily tomorrow
   - BAL today
   - f/u repeat vasculitis serologies
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will convert [**Last Name (un) 614**] to cipro
   - see below for CHF management
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   .
   #. Chronic Systolic CHF: Pt with last known EF of 40%. Now appears to
   be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion.
   Diuresis unsuccessful yesterday, per report, now appears to be
   improving according to physician at OSH.
   - repeat TTE this morning
   - will place on lasix gtt this morning, goal (-) 2 to 2.5 liters today
   - favor optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction -> will start
   isosorbide mononitrate, avoid ACEi given tenuous renal fxn, B blockade
   given 1^st degree AV block
   .
   # CAD s/p angioplasty, stent x 1:  troponin elevated, CK and MB
   normal.  Given recent history of hemoptysis and possible RML
   hemorrhage, renal insufficiency, and no significant ECG changes from
   admission to OSH, will defer anti-platelet and anti-coagulation at this
   time.  Will continue to trend and continue ASA 325 mg daily
   - hold statin in setting of transaminitis
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: DDx includes prerenal azotemia (poor
   forward flow, intravascular depletion), intrinsic, post-renal. Although
   now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.  No signs of acidosis,
   hyperkalemia to sugest urgent emergeny need for dialysis. Pt may
   require HD vs CVVH given azotemia.  Steroid-induced catabolic state
   likely etiology of elevated BUN.
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   - UA with sediment and cx
   - Urine Lytes
   - f/u Renal recs, appreciate recs
   .
   #.  Hypernatremia- suspect intravascular volume depletion in setting of
   recent diuresis and elevated BUN, serum osmolality.
   -  will correct free water deficit with D5W, 1.7 liters to correct to
   148 in next 8 hours
   -  serial Na
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, coronary artery disease, chronic systolic heart failure, renal failure, hypernatremia, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral vascular disease. He presented from an outside hospital with a vent setting of 10 PEEP and 40% FiO2, and was found to have a PaO2 of 60 on FiO2 and PEEP 10. The differential diagnosis includes chronic heart failure, ANCA-associated vasculitis, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and obstructive lung disease.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including bronchoscopy, blood cultures, and imaging studies. He has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors. His blood sugar levels have been difficult to control due to access issues.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 171/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His respiratory support includes a ventilator with a set tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has chronic systolic heart failure, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he may require dialysis to manage his electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium level is elevated, which may lead to further complications such as seizures or coma if not corrected.
5. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's blood sugar levels are elevated, and he may require insulin therapy to manage his diabetes.
6. Infection: The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but he may still be at risk for infection due to his compromised immune system and prolonged hospitalization.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's chest imaging studies have shown evidence of pneumonia, which may require further treatment with antibiotics and respiratory support.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's electrocardiogram shows a first-degree atrioventricular block, which may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
9. Pulmonary edema: The patient's chest imaging studies have shown evidence of pulmonary edema, which may worsen his respiratory function and increase his risk of cardiac complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address his multiple medical complications and prevent further deterioration.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.    Assessment and Plan:  83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from
   OSH with acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and
   acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome,
   VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).
   Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to moderate
   restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were
   noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart
   failure, as evidence by TTE, likely primary component.
   - son to attempt to obtain non-cont CT chest done prior to [**2139-1-5**]
   bronch
   - will cont to wean methylpred to 40 mg daily tomorrow
   - BAL today
   - f/u repeat vasculitis serologies
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will convert [**Last Name (un) 614**] to cipro
   - see below for CHF management
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   .

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic systolic heart failure. He has a history of type II diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, and chronic kidney injury. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, with a tracheostomy tube in place. He has been receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 171/75 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 97% on 40% FiO2. His respiratory support includes a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O and an inspiratory pressure (IP) of 28 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of chronic kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 2.2 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 25 mL/min. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 200 mg/dL, and his serum osmolality is 320 mOsm/kg. His troponin level is elevated, and his CK and MB levels are normal.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of left ventricular enlargement, moderate pulmonary edema, and moderate nonhemorrhagic bilateral pleural effusions. His chest CT scan also shows a small right middle lobe hematoma and moderate emphysema.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney injury may worsen, leading to renal failure.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to complications such as seizures and coma.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to confusion, agitation, and other behavioral changes.
6. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia and urinary tract infections.
7. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Thrombosis: The patient's hypercoagulable state may increase his risk of thrombosis, particularly deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs closely, including oxygen saturation, heart rate, and blood pressure.
3. Continue to treat the patient's hypernatremia with D5W and serial sodium monitoring.
4. Continue to manage the patient's altered mental status with daily awakenings and weaning of sedation.
5. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely, including creatinine, BUN, and troponin levels.
6. Continue to treat the patient's infection with antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
7. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider prophylactic anticoagulation therapy.
8. Monitor the patient's thrombotic risk and consider prophylactic anticoagulation therapy.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney injury, who presented to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, hypernatremia, and altered mental status. He has been diagnosed with bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show elevated troponin and creatinine levels, and he has been prescribed medications to manage his heart failure, chronic kidney injury, and hypernatremia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):** The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and BOOP diagnosis increase his risk of developing ARDS.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient's elevated white blood cell count and presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes in his bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL) suggest the possibility of sepsis.
3. **Heart Failure:** The patient's systolic heart failure and elevated troponin levels increase his risk of further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
4. **Renal Failure:** The patient's chronic kidney injury and elevated creatinine levels increase his risk of acute kidney injury or further decline in renal function.
5. **Hypernatremia:** The patient's hypernatremia increases his risk of central nervous system complications, such as seizures or coma.
6. **Diabetes Mellitus:** The patient's type II diabetes and elevated glucose levels increase his risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome.
7. **Pneumonia:** The patient's presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes in his BAL fluid and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of pneumonia.
8. **Vascular Complications:** The patient's chronic kidney injury and elevated troponin levels increase his risk of developing vascular complications, such as atherosclerosis or vasculitis.
9. **Infection:** The patient's presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes in his BAL fluid and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infection.
10. **Mental Status Changes:** The patient's altered mental status and history of sedation increase his risk of developing further cognitive impairment or delirium.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management plan as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation regimen as needed.
6. Consider performing a stat troponin level to rule out a myocardial infarction.
7. Consider performing a stat creatinine level to rule out acute kidney injury.
8. Consider performing a stat urine analysis to rule out urinary tract infection.
9. Consider performing a stat blood culture to rule out sepsis.
10. Consider performing a stat chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory failure, renal failure, and chronic systolic heart failure. He has a history of coronary artery disease, angioplasty, and stent placement. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a vent setting of 10 PEEP and 40% FiO2. He has a tracheostomy tube and is receiving antibiotics for a suspected Klebsiella pneumonia. The patient's labs show elevated troponin and creatinine, and he has a history of hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to chronic systolic heart failure and may worsen if not managed properly.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to prerenal azotemia and may worsen if not managed properly.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to free water deficit and may worsen if not managed properly.
4. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus is likely exacerbating his hypernatremia and may worsen if not managed properly.
5. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient's coronary artery disease may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac complications.
6. Chronic Systolic Heart Failure: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac complications.
7. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: The patient's acute on chronic kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to renal complications.
8. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to uremia and may worsen if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuresis as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with free water and monitor sodium levels.
4. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes mellitus with insulin and monitor blood glucose levels.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust sedation as needed.
7. Consider performing a non-contrast CT chest to evaluate for any pulmonary emboli.
8. Consider performing a stress test to evaluate for any cardiac complications.
9. Consider performing a renal ultrasound to evaluate for any renal complications.
10. Consider performing a blood culture to evaluate for any bloodstream infections.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, renal failure, and hypernatremia. He has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 8 cmH2O. His last P02 was 60 on FiO2 40% and PEEP 10.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a BUN of 200 mg/dL. He is receiving diuresis and has a goal of Na 144.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has a sodium level of 159 mg/dL and a free water deficit likely due to mechanical ventilation.
* Altered mental status: The patient is sedated and has not been alert or interactive since admission.
* Type II diabetes mellitus: The patient is being converted to insulin glargine.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his oxygenation and ventilation are not optimized.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed appropriately.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to seizures, cerebral edema, and increased intracranial pressure if not corrected.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen if his sedation is not weaned appropriately.
5. Type II diabetes mellitus: The patient's type II diabetes mellitus may worsen if not managed appropriately, leading to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.
6. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and renal failure may increase his risk of developing infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure and coronary artery disease may worsen if not managed appropriately, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to optimize the patient's oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his diuresis and fluid management accordingly.
3. Correct the patient's hypernatremia with D5W and monitor his sodium level closely.
4. Wean the patient's sedation daily and attempt to awaken him.
5. Manage the patient's type II diabetes mellitus with insulin glargine and monitor his blood glucose level closely.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory and cardiac status closely and adjust his management accordingly.
7. Consider antibiotic therapy if the patient develops a suspected infection.

Summary:

The patient is a 105.5 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory failure and renal failure. He is sedated and unresponsive, unable to provide a history. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, and type II diabetes. He has also been diagnosed with acute renal failure, hypernatremia, and peripheral vascular disease.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient has undergone bronchoscopy and ultrasound examinations. His respiratory status has been managed with mechanical ventilation, and he has been receiving antibiotics, insulin, and diuretics. His laboratory results show elevated liver function tests, likely due to cholecystitis, and a right pleural effusion.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.4°F)
* Heart rate: 96 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 141/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 35 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

His laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 24.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 108 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27 mmol/L
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 159 mg/dL, potassium 4.5 mmol/L, chloride 110 mmol/L
* Lactic acid: 2.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* LDH: 417 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may be at risk for further decline in renal function.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and chronic heart failure puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac failure.
* Infections: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central venous catheters and urinary catheters increase his risk for infections.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of cholecystitis and presence of a nasogastric tube increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding and perforation.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and sedation increase his risk for neurological complications such as seizures and brain injury.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure, presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and acute kidney injury. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. He has developed hypotension, fever, and worsening renal function, requiring dopamine support and vasopressors. He also has thrombocytopenia, anemia, and hyperkalemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Worsening systolic heart failure
	* Cardiogenic shock
	* Myocardial ischemia
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory failure
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
	* Uremic complications (e.g., hyperkalemia, acidosis)
	* Need for emergent hemodialysis
4. Hematological Complications:
	* Thrombocytopenia
	* Anemia
5. Infectious Complications:
	* Bacteremia
	* VAP
	* Central nervous system infection
6. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperkalemia
	* Hyperglycemia
	* Acidosis
7. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Hypotension
	* Cardiac arrhythmias
	* Cardiac tamponade

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

1. Cardiac support: Dopamine and vasopressors to support blood pressure and cardiac function.
2. Respiratory support: Mechanical ventilation and bronchodilators to manage respiratory failure.
3. Renal support: Hemodialysis and vasopressors to manage acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia.
4. Hematological support: Platelet transfusions and blood transfusions to manage thrombocytopenia and anemia.
5. Infectious disease management: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungals to manage potential infections.
6. Metabolic management: Insulin and electrolyte management to manage hyperglycemia and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Cardiovascular management: Monitoring for cardiac arrhythmias and tamponade.

The patient's son has been informed of the patient's condition and the plan of care, and has indicated that the patient would want all care only so long as there is a reasonable chance of his returning to his independent lifestyle.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, systolic heart failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP). The patient has a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and type II diabetes.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has systolic heart failure with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. The patient is receiving dopamine to support cardiac output and is being treated with lasix and isosorbide to reduce afterload.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 2.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 200 mg/dL. The patient is receiving dopamine and lasix to support renal function.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.4 g/dL and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 64,000/mL.
* Infectious disease status: The patient has a fever and is being treated empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. The patient's blood culture and respiratory culture are pending.
* Neurological status: The patient is sedated and unresponsive.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and hypotension increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's systolic heart failure and cardiac ischemia increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen and lead to respiratory arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury can worsen and lead to end-stage renal disease.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy increase the risk of bleeding.
* Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state increases the risk of infection, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. The patient's treatment plan should be individualized to address his specific needs and comorbidities.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male who is intubated and sedated in the ICU due to acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, chronic systolic heart failure, and acute kidney injury. The patient's condition is complex and requires careful management.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (101°F)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/39 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 24.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 6.4 g/dL
* Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 200 mg/dL
* Sodium: 173 mg/dL
* Potassium: 5.9 mEq/L
* Chloride: 103 mEq/L
* Bicarbonate: 21.0 mEq/L
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.1 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 1.00 ng/mL
* CK: 736 IU/L
* CK-MB: 8 IU/L
* ALT: 92 IU/L
* AST: 58 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 82 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 0.9 mg/dL
* Direct bilirubin: 0.1 mg/dL
* Fibrinogen: 300 mg/dL
* LDH: 630 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 6.3 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by the presence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), which is likely secondary to aspiration or infection. The patient's heart failure is chronic systolic, and the patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with a stent.

The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen of 200 mg/dL. The patient's electrolyte imbalance is significant, with a sodium of 173 mg/dL, potassium of 5.9 mEq/L, and chloride of 103 mEq/L.

The patient's mental status is altered, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3. The patient is sedated and has not been alert or interactive since admission.

The patient's medications include:

* Dopamine: 10 mcg/kg/min
* Lasix: 40 mg/day
* Isosorbide: 20 mg/day
* Aspirin: 325 mg/day
* Heparin: 5,000 units/day
* Ranitidine: 150 mg/day
* Insulin: 10 units/day

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Renal failure
* Hyperkalemia
* Hypermagnesemia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Infection

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs
* Management of respiratory status with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Management of cardiac status with dopamine and lasix
* Management of kidney function with aggressive diuresis and close monitoring of electrolytes
* Management of electrolyte imbalance with administration of electrolyte solutions
* Management of mental status with daily awakenings and sedation as needed
* Conversion to insulin therapy for glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with pneumatic compression boots and low-molecular-weight heparin
* Prophylaxis for stress ulcer with ranitidine
* Prophylaxis for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with antibiotics

The patient's disposition is pending, but the plan is to transfer him to a hospital unit for further care and management.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following are the key findings and potential medical complications:

**Cardiovascular:**

* Hypotension (shock)
* Chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with a last known EF of 40%
* Coronary artery disease (CAD) with a history of angioplasty and stenting
* Worsening ST depression in I, aVL on ECG

Potential complications:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Cardiac arrest
* Heart failure exacerbation

**Respiratory:**

* Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) on imaging
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) noted on CT chest from outside hospital

Potential complications:

* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

**Renal:**

* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a last known creatinine of 2.0
* Hyperkalemia (potassium level of 7.0 mg/dL)

Potential complications:

* Dialysis requirement
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Renal failure

**Endocrine:**

* Type II diabetes mellitus (DM)
* Hypernatremia (sodium level of 149 mmol/L)

Potential complications:

* Diabetic ketoacidosis
* Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome (HHNS)

**Neurological:**

* Altered mental status (AMS)
* Sedation held for a period of time without improvement

Potential complications:

* Increased intracranial pressure
* Seizures
* Neurological deterioration

**Infectious:**

* Positive bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) culture for Klebsiella, resistant to ciprofloxacin
* Possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

Potential complications:

* Sepsis
* Organ failure
* Death

**Other:**

* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Peripheral vascular disease (PVD)
* Anemia

Potential complications:

* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Cardiovascular events

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple complications, including cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, endocrine, and neurological events. Close monitoring and aggressive management of these conditions are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male who is intubated and sedated, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score not assessed. The patient is being treated in the ICU for acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and cardiac issues.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (101°F)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/39 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic systolic heart failure, and type II diabetes mellitus. He has also been diagnosed with acute renal failure and is receiving dopamine infusion for hypotension.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 24.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 6.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 64 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 1.00 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* LDH: 630 IU/L

The patient's microbiology results show:

* Gram stain of bronchoalveolar lavage: 1+ polymorphonuclear leukocytes, no microorganisms seen
* Respiratory culture: no growth, <1000 CFU/mL
* Immunofluorescent test for Pneumocystis jirovecii: negative

The patient's ECG shows worsening ST depression in I and aVL.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and chronic systolic heart failure puts him at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and heart failure.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's acute respiratory failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) put him at risk for respiratory complications, such as respiratory acidosis, hypoxemia, and respiratory failure.
* Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure and chronic kidney disease put him at risk for renal complications, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Infectious complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines and arterial lines put him at risk for infectious complications, such as sepsis, catheter-related bloodstream infections, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Metabolic complications: The patient's diabetes mellitus and electrolyte imbalances put him at risk for metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and sedation put him at risk for neurological complications, such as delirium, seizures, and brain herniation.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his various medical conditions to prevent complications and improve his outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI.
   Course complicated by hypotension.
 ? Cardiogenic SHOCK  -  Persistently low central venous oxygen
   saturation certainly suggests low cardiac output.   Cardiac enzymes are
   rather confusing, however the fact that the troponins have peaked
   before the CKs, and that the MB fraction is essentially negative likely
   suggests a past cardiac event of uncertain age given ARF, with current
   muscular hypoperfusion in the setting of known PVD.  Given fever,
   infection vs. anemia leading to demand ischemia in past is most likely
   scenario.  See below for fever eval.  Would continue dopamine given
   myocardial ischemia.  Will not start heparin as ischemia likely demand
   and would likely be exacerbated by bleeding.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30
   - Continue Dopamine
   - Trend lactate, Cardiac Enzymes, CVO2
   - ?vigileo to assess stroke volume
   - pan culture, start vanc/zosyn empirically, see below
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Patient has not been
   alert/interactive since transfer.  Currently off sedation, would await
   correction of uremia before undertaking any more invasive diagnostic
   endeavors.
   - will attempt daily awakenings, hold sedation
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds and melena clinically.  GI
   has been consulted but I doubt they would scope him in his current
   condition.  Bright red blood has never been expressed on NG lavage.
   - GI RECS
   - DDAVP to address oozing
   - 2 units platelets
   .
   > ANEMIA/thrombocytopenia
 no evidence of hemolysis.  Pt does have
   progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets.  Bumped
   appropriately to 4 units.  While no evidence of hemolysis on smear or
   labs, patient has thrombocytopenia, fever, altered mental status, and
   renal faillure.  Still unlikely to be TTP.
   -Transfuse for HCT>30, PLT>50 given GI bleeding
   - Ferritin elevated, inconsistent with iron deficiency anemia
   .
   > FEVER
 etiology includes VAP, bacteremia from lines; abdominal
   infection, CNS infection less likely
   - will pan-culture, start zosyn/vanc empirically
   - if PICC line looks like source, will remove, re-site
   - treat fever for transfusion
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last
   p02 of 60 on FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of
   failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from
   OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to
   moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **],
   ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat here.  Path
   report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear RML
   hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart failure, as evidence by
   TTE, is likely the primary component.
   - will upload CT from [**2138-12-22**]
   - steroids increased to pulse dose
   - f/u BAL results, (-) thus far
   - repeat vasculitis serologies are negative
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will cont cipro today day [**4-15**]
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   - wean vent
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - cont dopamine
   - cont ASA
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.
   Steroid-induced catabolic state combined with GI bleed likely etiology
   of elevated BUN.  Creatinine and urine output worsening in setting of
   hypotension and possible cardiogenic vs. septic shock.  Hyperkalemia
   progressing.
   - Continue CVVH
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 had to restart insulin drip
   .
   ..
   FEN: hold TF/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC, left a-line
   .
   Full Code
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .

   IU/L, Ca++:9.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:6.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI.
   Course complicated by hypotension.
 ? Cardiogenic SHOCK  -  Persistently low central venous oxygen
   saturation certainly suggests low cardiac output.   Cardiac enzymes are
   rather confusing, however the fact that the troponins have peaked
   before the CKs, and that the MB fraction is essentially negative likely
   suggests a past cardiac event of uncertain age given ARF, with current
   muscular hypoperfusion in the setting of known PVD.  Given fever,
   infection vs. anemia leading to demand ischemia in past is most likely
   scenario.  See below for fever eval.  Would continue dopamine given
   myocardial ischemia.  Will not start heparin as ischemia likely demand
   and would likely be exacerbated by bleeding.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30
   - Continue Dopamine
   - Trend lactate, Cardiac Enzymes, CVO2
   - ?vigileo to assess stroke volume
   - pan culture, start vanc/zosyn empirically, see below
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Patient has not been
   alert/interactive since transfer.  Currently off sedation, would await
   correction of uremia before undertaking any more invasive diagnostic
   endeavors.
   - will attempt daily awakenings, hold sedation
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds and melena clinically.  GI
   has been consulted but I doubt they would scope him in his current
   condition.  Bright red blood has never been expressed on NG lavage.
   - GI RECS
   - DDAVP to address oozing
   - 2 units platelets
   .
   > ANEMIA/thrombocytopenia
 no evidence of hemolysis.  Pt does have
   progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets.  Bumped
   appropriately to 4 units.  While no evidence of hemolysis on smear or
   labs, patient has thrombocytopenia, fever, altered mental status, and
   renal faillure.  Still unlikely to be TTP.
   -Transfuse for HCT>30, PLT>50 given GI bleeding
   - Ferritin elevated, inconsistent with iron deficiency anemia
   .
   > FEVER
 etiology includes VAP, bacteremia from lines; abdominal
   infection, CNS infection less likely
   - will pan-culture, start zosyn/vanc empirically
   - if PICC line looks like source, will remove, re-site
   - treat fever for transfusion
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last
   p02 of 60 on FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of
   failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from
   OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to
   moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **],
   ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat here.  Path
   report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear RML
   hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart failure, as evidence by
   TTE, is likely the primary component.
   - will upload CT from [**2138-12-22**]
   - steroids increased to pulse dose
   - f/u BAL results, (-) thus far
   - repeat vasculitis serologies are negative
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will cont cipro today day [**4-15**]
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   - wean vent
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - cont dopamine
   - cont ASA
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.
   Steroid-induced catabolic state combined with GI bleed likely etiology
   of elevated BUN.  Creatinine and urine output worsening in setting of
   hypotension and possible cardiogenic vs. septic shock.  Hyperkalemia
   progressing.
   - Continue CVVH
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 had to restart insulin drip
   .
   ..
   FEN: hold TF/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC, left a-line
   .
   Full Code
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with systolic heart failure, acute hypoxic respiratory failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient's condition is complicated by hypotension, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and fever.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (101°F)
* Heart rate: 98 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 152/78 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 32 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Mixed venous oxygen saturation: 42-57%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 38.0 K/μL
* Hematocrit: 34.5%
* Platelet count: 30 K/μL
* Creatinine: 2.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 200 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 1.41 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 3.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* LDH: 630 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 6.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Cardiogenic shock
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP)
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Fever
* Respiratory failure
* Coronary artery disease (CAD)
* Diabetes mellitus (DM), type II

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH)
* Dopamine infusion
* Pantoprazole drip
* Heparin prophylaxis
* Steroids for BOOP
* Antibiotics for suspected infection
* CVVH protocol for fluid management
* Pain management
* Bowel regimen
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further deterioration of cardiogenic shock
* Progression of AKI
* Development of sepsis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Respiratory failure
* Coronary artery disease progression
* Hyperkalemia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hypophosphatemia

The patient's disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities, including:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's central venous oxygen saturation is persistently low, suggesting low cardiac output. Cardiac enzymes are elevated, but the troponin levels have peaked before the creatine kinase (CK) levels, suggesting a past cardiac event of uncertain age.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has not been alert or interactive since transfer to the ICU. He is currently off sedation, and daily awakenings will be attempted once his uremia is corrected.
3. GI bleed: The patient has coffee grounds on his nasogastric (NG) lavage, indicating upper GI bleeding. GI has been consulted, but it is unlikely that they will scope him in his current condition.
4. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient has progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets. He has not had a hemolytic reaction, but his platelet count is low, and he has a fever, altered mental status, and renal failure.
5. Fever: The etiology of the fever is unclear, but it could be related to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), bacteremia from lines, or abdominal infection.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute hypoxic respiratory failure, which is likely related to his systolic heart failure and possible chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
7. Coronary artery disease (CAD): The patient has evidence of worsening ischemia laterally in the I and aVL leads, and his CK and troponin levels are elevated.
8. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF), which is likely related to prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal failure, or a combination of both.
9. Diabetes mellitus (DM), type II: The patient has had to restart his insulin drip.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiogenic shock and low cardiac output may increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
3. GI bleeding: The patient's upper GI bleeding may worsen, leading to hypovolemic shock and multi-organ failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to uremic toxicity and multi-organ failure.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and multi-organ failure.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate an infection, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
7. CAD: The patient's CAD may worsen, leading to myocardial infarction and multi-organ failure.

To manage these potential complications, the patient will require close monitoring and aggressive treatment, including:

1. Cardiovascular support: The patient will require dopamine to support his cardiac output, and his blood pressure will need to be carefully monitored.
2. Respiratory support: The patient will require continued mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function.
3. Renal support: The patient will require continued CVVH to support his renal function.
4. GI support: The patient will require continued NG suction and possible endoscopy to evaluate and manage his upper GI bleeding.
5. Infection control: The patient will require broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat his suspected VAP and other potential infections.
6. CAD management: The patient will require continued ASA therapy to manage his CAD, and his cardiac enzymes will need to be closely monitored.
7. Pain management: The patient will require aggressive pain management to minimize his discomfort and anxiety.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex medical case with multiple comorbidities and potential complications. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment will be necessary to manage his condition and prevent further deterioration.

   MICU ATTENDING ADDENDUM
   On this day I examined Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] and reviewed the events of the last
   24hr along with his lab and imaging data. I was present for the key
   portions of the services provided and have read Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 11097**]
s note
   above.  I agree with his findings and plan of care.
   As noted in my note from [**1-25**], the pt remains very critically ill with
   multiorgan system failure, including resp failure, renal failure, coma,
   UGI bleeding, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia.  We are continuing
   aggressive medical interventions, including:
   1)       resp failure: continuing mech vent support, now with A/C with
   increased VT to help with air hunger. He
s now been ventilated for
   approx 3 wks. No evidence of new resp infection
   2)       GI bleed: now on IV PPI and has gotten plts and DDAVP. Heparin
   for cardiac status has been avoided, given his bleeding.  GI aware of
   pt but would not EGD unless evidence of ongoing bleeding. In retrospect
   his GI bleeding may have been contributing to rising BUN.
   3)       Hypotension: likely due to cardiac ischemia, poor LVEF, and GI
   bleed in the setting of continuous HD. Actually his dopamine
   requirement is lower today and SBP 120, and perhaps we can wean Dopa
   off.
   4)       Anemia: got 4 units rbc yesterday and will continue to support
   for Hct less than 30.
   5)       Thrombocytopenia: Unclear why plts are so low. Stopped
   ranitidine yesterday. He
s not been on heparin. Will support for plts
   under 50k
   6)       Renal failure: Getting continuous CVVHD and BUN decreasing,
   HCO stable, but so far no improvement in mental status
   7)       Fever, leukocytosis: WBC up to 33k from 24k of past few days.
   Being covered broadly with zosyn and vanc pending culture results
   8)       Unresponsiveness: This is a crucial issue to family.  Dialysis
   ongoing to see if any improvement in mentation as BUN gets below 90 and
   SBP remains over 100. CT just last week showed no cause for current
   obtundation.  If other organ systems improve and mentation doesn
   further neuro assessment may be in order.
   9)       Family communication and pt wishes: I
ve spoken to son [**Name (NI) 453**]
   and daughter [**Name (NI) 4097**] at some length and have explained the gravity of
   Mr [**Known lastname 12627**]
 current multiorgan system failure predicament. I have asked
   them to consider DNR status, given the lack of likely effectiveness of
   CPR in this settting. They will discuss this and get back to team. I
   also told them that this is a very unstable situation and that unless
   several things improve quickly, such as in the next couple of days, I
   didn
t see how Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] could survive all these insults, especially
   given his severe CAD
   75 min spent in the care of this very critically ill patient
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1620**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1621**], MD
