progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic
   platelets, with ?contribution of HIT.   Appears to have consumptive
   process since losing transfused plts rapidly. PT and PTT now
   normalized. Fibrinogen nl.  Heparin and vanc stopped.  Pantoprazole
   could be etiology.
   - transfuse to goal 10, 50 if increased bleeding
   - send HIT and serotonin assay
   - consider holding nonessential meds
   - Would hold off on anti-coagulation at least until SRA returns
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving very gradually.  We
   will continue off sedation.  Likely [**2-10**] poor hepatic clearance of
   sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Patient
   now answering questions, following commands.  Able to move lower
   extremities, not upper extremities.  MRI shows prior right MCA infarct,
   nothing acute.
   - cont CVVH likely [**1-10**] more days until BUN in 20
   - f/u repeat EEG
   - will D/C meropenem on [**2-3**] for course of Klebsiella therapy, very low
   suspicion for nosocomial bacterial meningitis
   .
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - will need to restart anti-platelet therapy when GI bleed resolves
   - recheck ECG this morning
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
   - appreciate renal recs
   .
   #. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS: Pt has LFTs c/w ischemic injury, now trending
   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Fam mtg yesterday. Fam aware of poor prognosis given
   multiorgan failure. Hope is that mental status improves with CVVH,
   otherwise it will be clear that patient will not return to his baseline
   and they would favor withdrawing care. Will give CVVH another day or
   so.
   ..
   FEN: hold TF, will start TPN/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .
   CODE STATUS:  DNR
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .
   DISPOSITION:  [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] pending above

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure, acute hypoexmic respiratory failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). He has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory support and management of his underlying conditions. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal bleeding, and pancytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires ongoing ventilatory support. The risk of respiratory failure is high, and the patient may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is likely due to a combination of factors, including his underlying conditions and the medications he is receiving. The risk of bleeding and infection is high, and the patient may require transfusions and antibiotic therapy.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is ongoing, and he requires ongoing transfusions and supportive care. The risk of further bleeding is high, and the patient may require further interventions such as endoscopy or surgery.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he requires ongoing dialysis therapy. The risk of further renal deterioration is high, and the patient may require further interventions such as kidney transplantation.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is compromised, and he requires ongoing cardiac monitoring and therapy. The risk of further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias, is high.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is compromised, and he requires ongoing neurological monitoring and therapy. The risk of further neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke, is high.
7. Infection: The patient is at high risk of infection, particularly with multi-drug resistant organisms. The risk of sepsis and septic shock is high, and the patient may require further interventions such as antibiotics and source control.
8. Hepatic Complications: The patient's liver function is compromised, and he requires ongoing liver function monitoring and therapy. The risk of further hepatic complications, such as liver failure, is high.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to provide ongoing ventilatory support and respiratory therapy to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pancytopenia with transfusions and antibiotic therapy as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding with transfusions and supportive care as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with dialysis therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and provide ongoing cardiac therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and provide ongoing neurological therapy as needed.
7. Consider further interventions such as antibiotics and source control to manage the patient's risk of infection.
8. Consider further interventions such as liver transplantation to manage the patient's hepatic complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. The patient's chief complaint is respiratory distress, which was managed with increased ventilator support. Notable findings include:

1. Decreased cardiac beats with a pulse of 30-40, stable blood pressure, and decreased cardiac output.
2. Leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and unclear indication for Meropenem, which was discontinued.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding, upper and lower, with ongoing melena and GI bleed.
4. Acute respiratory failure, not ARDS, with increased oxygen requirements and mechanical ventilation.
5. Chronic systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and peripheral vascular disease.
6. Acute renal failure, hypernatremia, and diabetes mellitus, type II.
7. Altered mental status, not delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Cardiac complications: decreased cardiac output, cardiac arrhythmias, and potential for cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: worsening respiratory failure, pneumonia, and potential for respiratory arrest.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: ongoing bleeding, perforation, and potential for sepsis.
4. Renal complications: worsening acute renal failure, electrolyte imbalance, and potential for renal failure.
5. Neurological complications: worsening altered mental status, potential for seizures, and potential for neurological deterioration.
6. Infection-related complications: sepsis, septic shock, and potential for multi-organ failure.

The patient's ongoing medical treatment includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation with CMV mode.
2. Ongoing IV fluids and electrolyte replacement.
3. Antibiotic therapy, pending further evaluation of the patient's microbiology results.
4. Glycemic control with insulin therapy.
5. Prophylactic measures for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
6. Nutrition support with TPN and lipids.

Given the patient's complex medical status, close monitoring and ongoing assessment are necessary to address potential complications and optimize treatment outcomes.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 105.5 kg elderly individual with a chief complaint of hypoxia and acute respiratory failure (ARF). The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, with increasing support required during spontaneous breathing trials. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable blood pressure, but the patient has a significant fluid imbalance, with a total input of 8,469 mL and output of 10,914 mL over 24 hours.

The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, ventilator mode set to CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, and a FiO2 of 50%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.44, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 180, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 31.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, but the patient has a bigeminal rhythm and is in atrial fibrillation. The patient's neurologic examination shows the patient is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 2.6, hemoglobin (Hb) of 10.7 g/dL, and platelet count (Plt) of 56. The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium (K+) level of 4.6 mEq/L, magnesium (Mg++) level of 1.9 mg/dL, and phosphorus (PO4) level of 2.9 mg/dL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 1138 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 247 IU/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying lung disease is unclear, and there is concern for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COP) on transbronchial biopsy. The patient has also had bleeding into the right middle lobe (RML) after transbronchial biopsy, volume overload, and Klebsiella ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has completed 14 days of antibiotics for VAP and has been on high-dose steroids, which have been tapered off.
2. Renal failure, acute: The patient's trial off of continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) has been successful, and the patient has reasonable urine output. The patient's electrolytes will be followed, and intermittent hemodialysis (HD) may be required if necessary.
3. Thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been persistently low, and the patient has been experiencing bleeding into the RML. The patient's serotonin release assay is pending, and the patient is not being anti-coagulated currently due to gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).
4. Gastrointestinal bleed: The patient has had small amounts of bleeding into the RML, and the patient's hematocrit (Hct) is stable. The patient's gastrointestinal (GI) follow-up is ongoing, and the patient is not currently undergoing endoscopy or colonoscopy.
5. Bigeminy: The patient's heart rate has been decreasing to the low 60s, but the patient appears to be perfusing well.
6. Heart failure, chronic: The patient is still volume overloaded, and the patient's goal input/output (I/O) is 1 L negative over 24 hours.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium level has resolved with CVVH.
8. Diabetes mellitus, type II: The patient is on insulin subcutaneously (SC) and insulin in total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
9. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is likely due to toxicity or metabolic issues, and the patient's sedation has been held and CVVH has been used to clear uremia.

The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and the patient's disposition is to the medical intensive care unit (MICU).

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 95.7 kg elderly individual who has been admitted to the ICU due to hypoxia and acute respiratory failure (ARF). The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has shown improvement in oxygenation, but still requires high levels of oxygen support.

The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, and has been running negative on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to fluid overload. The patient's kidney function is impaired, and the plan is to trial off CVVH and monitor electrolytes.

The patient has developed thrombocytopenia and is at risk for bleeding, particularly due to the presence of bigeminy and chronic heart failure. The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is ongoing, but hemodynamically stable.

The patient has a history of type II diabetes mellitus and is receiving insulin therapy. The patient's mental status is altered, likely due to metabolic and toxic factors, and the plan is to continue weaning sedation and CVVH to clear uremia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation.
2. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and bigeminy.
3. Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to inadequate fluid management.
4. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to insulin therapy and altered glucose metabolism.
5. Electrolyte imbalance due to inadequate electrolyte management during CVVH.
6. Increased risk of cardiovascular events due to chronic heart failure and bigeminy.
7. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding and altered immune function.
8. Increased risk of aspiration pneumonia due to impaired swallowing and altered mental status.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient is in the ICU with respiratory failure, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, gastrointestinal bleed, bigeminy, chronic heart failure, hypernatremia, and altered mental status.

The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with ongoing need for mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. The patient's lung disease is unclear, and there is concern for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and pulmonary edema. The patient has also had a recent transbronchial biopsy with bleeding into the right middle lobe.

The patient's renal function is impaired, and they have been on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) therapy. The patient's platelet count is low, and they have a positive PF4 assay, which suggests a possible heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient is not currently receiving anticoagulation therapy due to gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and they are still experiencing small amounts of bleeding. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, but they are still at risk for further bleeding.

The patient's cardiac status is also compromised, with chronic heart failure and a recent episode of hypotension. The patient's electrolyte levels are being monitored closely, and they are receiving diuretic therapy to manage fluid overload.

The patient's mental status is altered, likely due to toxic or metabolic causes. The patient's diabetes is being managed with insulin therapy, and their nutritional needs are being met through total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation make them at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's compromised immune system and ongoing antibiotic therapy make them at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Bleeding: The patient's low platelet count and ongoing bleeding make them at risk for further bleeding complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure and need for dialysis therapy make them at risk for further kidney damage.
5. Cardiac arrest: The patient's chronic heart failure and compromised cardiac function make them at risk for cardiac arrest.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's altered mental status and need for insulin therapy make them at risk for developing metabolic acidosis.
7. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and ongoing antibiotic therapy make them at risk for developing further infections.

Overall, this patient requires close monitoring and management of their multiple comorbidities and complications to prevent further deterioration and optimize their chances of recovery.

   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]):
   Differential of initial failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated
   vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung
   disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to
   be consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are
   negative on repeat here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process
   is multifactorial: pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD
   with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology. Current barriers to
   extubation are CHF, muscular weakness, and underlying poor reserves.
   - cont PSV trial daily
   - likely will need trach since intubated 3 weeks and will need to
   regain strength prior to extubation
   - consult IP for trach/peg at bedside
   - now off steroids
   .
   >. FEVER/UTI: Pt febrile to 100.1 axillary. CXR this AM shows RLL
   infiltrate more concerning  for infection. Respiratory status
   unchanged, no increase secretions. Prior sputum has grown pan-[**Last Name (un) 270**]
   Klebsiella but has been hospitalized and intubated >3 weeks so high
   risk of resistant organisms.
   Also UA c/w infection, changed Foley and started vanco/cefepime for
   UTI. Line infection is also a concern, will monitor blood cx and D/C
   fem HD cath after HD tomorrow.
   - f/u cx
   - add cipro for pseudomonas double coverage
   - cont vanco/cefepime, renally dosed
   >. Pancytopenia
 Stopped meropenem which can cause pancytopenia, would
   continue to trend. Heme/onc thought drug-related although unclear why
   plts so low. HIT + but SRA pending. Smear unremarkable. Alternative
   explanation is that patient had baseline leucopenia prior to high dose
   steroids, and we are now seeing this return to baseline.
   - appreciate heme/onc recs
   - switch pantoprazole to ranitidine
   - send HIT + and serotonin assay
 pending
   - send SPEP, UPEP
   - Would hold off on anti-coagulation at least until SRA returns
   - consider BM bx
   - transfuse for Hct>28, Plt>10 unless bleeding
   - check [**Hospital1 7**] CBC
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
   - appreciate renal recs
   >  GI BLEED
 Likely lower GIB, unclear source and patient never
   bleeding enough to scope. Now improved with only oozing when rectum
   cleaned. Also having oral mucosal bleeding, with friable mucosa.
   - send HSV and CMV
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving Likely [**2-10**] poor
   hepatic clearance of sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic
   encephalopathy.  MRI showedrior right MCA infarct, nothing acute.
   Patient now improving towards baseline, interactive and appropriate.
   - trial off CVVH, BUN increasing and will have HD tomorrow
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver. Repeat TTE showed biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 28
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
   #. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS: Pt has LFTs c/w ischemic injury, now trending
   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Will readdress question of trach/PEG.
   ..

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, acute on chronic kidney injury, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient has been admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, hypoxemic, and is currently intubated.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Renal failure, acute (ARF): The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with a goal TBB of -1 to 2L today. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and has undergone multiple interventions, including hemodialysis.
2. Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin level. The patient's pancytopenia is likely due to drug-related causes, including meropenem, which can cause pancytopenia.
3. Fever and UTI: The patient has a fever of 100.1°F and a urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient's urine culture grew pan-resistant Klebsiella, and the patient is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime.
4. GI bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, including upper and lower GI bleeding. The patient's bleeding is likely due to a combination of factors, including medication use, poor perfusion, and underlying medical conditions.
5. Altered mental status: The patient has an altered mental status, which is likely due to a combination of factors, including poor hepatic clearance of sedatives, uremia, and recent brain injury.
6. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension, which is likely due to a combination of factors, including poor perfusion, medication use, and underlying medical conditions.
7. Coronary artery disease (CAD): The patient has a history of CAD, which is likely contributing to his current condition.
8. Biventricular systolic heart failure: The patient has a history of biventricular systolic heart failure, which is likely due to a combination of factors, including CAD, hypertension, and underlying medical conditions.
9. Ischemic hepatitis: The patient has a history of ischemic hepatitis, which is likely due to a combination of factors, including CAD, hypertension, and underlying medical conditions.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. CVVH with a goal TBB of -1 to 2L today
2. Antibiotic therapy for UTI
3. Medication management for pancytopenia
4. GI bleeding management
5. Altered mental status management
6. Hypotension management
7. CAD management
8. Biventricular systolic heart failure management
9. Ischemic hepatitis management

The patient's goals of care include readdressing the question of tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG). The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): Had been
   improving and requiring less and less support, however today after
   going to low level pressure support, after 30 minutes he became
   tachycardic, and tachypneic and required return to ventilatory support
   at CMV.  He also had some evidence of anxiety vs fatigue which is what
   I suspect the etiology of his tachypnea and decompensation was.  He
   rapidly recovered with no intervention making PE and Right sided MI
   unlikely.  X-ray was inconsistent with flash.
   .
    Differential of initial failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated
   vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung
   disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to
   be consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are
   negative on repeat here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process
   is multifactorial: pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD
   with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology.
   - cont PSV trials now that mental status improved
 did well yesterday
   with NIF of -20, RSBI of 53 yesterday
   - follow VBGs and ABGs prn
   - cont to wean steroids, would change to home dose today.
   .
   >. FEVER/UTI: Pt febrile to 100.1 axillary. No obvious source, no
   change on CXR or increase secretions. No ab pain/distention. UA c/w
   infection, changed Foley and started vanco/cefepime for UTI. Line
   infection is also a concern, will monitor blood cx and D/C fem HD cath
   after HD tomorrow.
   - f/u cx
   - cont vanco/cefepime, renally dosed
   >. Pancytopenia
 Stopped meropenem which can cause pancytopenia, would
   continue to trend. Heme/onc thought drug-related although unclear why
   plts so low. HIT + but SRA pending. Smear unremarkable.
   - appreciate heme/onc recs
   - consider BM bx
   - transfuse for Hct>21, Plt>10 unless bleeding
   .
   >  GI BLEED
 GI thinks this is lower, as low volume BRBPR with now
   resolved coffee grounds and melena.
   - GI says they will not scope and will not do tagged red cell scan
   - cont [**Hospital1 7**] pantoprazole
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia
progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic
   platelets, with ?contribution of HIT.   Appears to have consumptive
   process since losing transfused plts rapidly. PT and PTT now
   normalized. Fibrinogen nl.  Heparin and vanc stopped.  Pantoprazole
   could be etiology.
   - transfuse to goal 10, 50 if increased bleeding
   - send HIT + and serotonin assay
 pending
   - consider holding nonessential meds
   - Would hold off on anti-coagulation at least until SRA returns
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving very gradually.  We
   will continue off sedation.  Likely [**2-10**] poor hepatic clearance of
   sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Patient
   now answering questions, following commands.  Able to move lower
   extremities, not upper extremities.  MRI shows prior right MCA infarct,
   nothing acute.
   - trial off CVVH
   - f/u repeat EEG
   - will D/C meropenem.
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - will need to restart anti-platelet therapy when GI bleed resolves
   - recheck ECG this morning
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
   - appreciate renal recs
   .
   #. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS: Pt has LFTs c/w ischemic injury, now trending
   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Fam mtg yesterday. Fam aware of poor prognosis given
   multiorgan failure. Hope is that mental status improves with CVVH,
   otherwise it will be clear that patient will not return to his baseline
   and they would favor withdrawing care. Will give CVVH another day or
   so.
   ..
   FEN: hold TF, will start TPN/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .
   CODE STATUS:  DNR
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .
   DISPOSITION:  [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] pending above

   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - will need to restart anti-platelet therapy when GI bleed resolves
   - recheck ECG this morning
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
   - appreciate renal recs
   .
   #. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS: Pt has LFTs c/w ischemic injury, now trending
   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Fam mtg yesterday. Fam aware of poor prognosis given
   multiorgan failure. Hope is that mental status improves with CVVH,
   otherwise it will be clear that patient will not return to his baseline
   and they would favor withdrawing care. Will give CVVH another day or
   so.
   ..
   FEN: hold TF, will start TPN/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, acute hypoemic respiratory failure, and multiorgan failure. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failure, acute on chronic kidney injury, and is currently requiring mechanical ventilation and continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 100.1°F (axillary)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 147/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 2.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 56 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.49 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 424 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Systolic heart failure
* Acute hypoemic respiratory failure
* Chronic kidney injury
* Multiorgan failure
* Hypotension
* Fever
* Pancytopenia
* Thrombocytopenia
* GI bleed
* Ischemic heart disease
* Biventricular systolic heart failure
* Renal failure, acute
* Ischemic hepatitis
* Diabetes mellitus, type II

The patient's medications include:

* Meropenem (stopped)
* Cefepime
* Vancomycin
* Pantoprazole
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Insulin drip
* TPN with lipids

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
* Monitoring LFTs daily
* Holding any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
* Transfusing to HCT>30 in setting of demand ischemia
* Off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
* Cont to trend LFTs, improving
* Trial off CVVH
* F/u repeat EEG
* Will D/C meropenem
* Continue to wean steroids, would change to home dose today
* Follow VBGs and ABGs prn
* Cont to monitor blood cx and D/C fem HD cath after HD tomorrow
* Consider BM bx
* Transfuse for Hct>21, Plt>10 unless bleeding

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions and medications include:

* Further decline in renal function
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and GI bleed
* Worsening of heart failure and cardiac function
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppression
* Further decline in mental status
* Development of respiratory failure or worsening of existing respiratory failure
* Development of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
* Development of hepatic failure or worsening of existing liver dysfunction
* Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disturbances

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to address any potential complications and optimize his care.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infiltrates, complicated
   by multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).
   Gradual signs of clinical improvement.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).   Now multifactorial
   (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, underlying COPD).  Now
   evidence for new VAP (RLL infiltrate).  Continue steroids --> taper,
   continue antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider
   tracheostomy if no contined progress, family considering long-term
   option.  Consult IP service for trach/PEG.
   MOTOR WEAKNESS, GENERALIZED -- attributed to ICU neuropathy (attributed
   to steroids and paralytic use).  Anticipate gradual recovery.
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  A-line d/c'd.  Plan continue antimicrobials to
   full course.
   FEVER -- Attributed in part to bacteremia.  Monitor temperature.
   HYPOTENSION --  Currently improved.  Monitor BP, maintain MAP > 60
   mmHg.
   CAD -- recent evidence for myocardial damage --> possible demand
   ischemia.  Now stable.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of profound thrombocytopenia.  Maintain
   venous access, serial Hct, transfuse.  Transfuse plts, correct
   coagulopathy, dDAVP.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN.  Now off CVVH since yesterday.
   Monitor intrinsic renal function.
   ANEMIA -- multifactorial.  Now evidence for blood loss, GI source.
   Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 28.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose
   <150.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- attributed to HIT+ and in part to mediations
   (meropenem, pentoprozol).  [**Month (only) 51**] be attributed to active GI bleed
   (consumption).  Monitor.   Hematology consultation in progress.
   HIT+ -- avoid heparin.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 tolerating TF.  D/C TPN.
   LFT ABNORMALITIES -- consistent with shock liver.  Continues to resolve
   slowly.
   DISPOSITION -- DNR currently.  Maintain discussions with family.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a critically ill 83-year-old male who has been in the ICU for an unknown duration. He is mechanically ventilated and has profound motor weakness.

The patient's condition is complicated by multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient has been diagnosed with:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray, which are multifactorial in origin, including diffuse pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is receiving steroids and antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.
2. Motor weakness, generalized: The patient's motor weakness is attributed to ICU neuropathy caused by the use of steroids and paralytics. The patient is expected to have gradual recovery.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for gram-positive cocci (GPC), which is likely related to a central line. He is receiving antimicrobials, and the central line has been discontinued.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is attributed in part to bacteremia and is being monitored.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved, and his blood pressure is being monitored.
6. CAD: The patient has recent evidence of myocardial damage, which may be due to demand ischemia. He is now stable.
7. Melena/hematocchia: The patient has unclear source of bleeding, which may be related to upper gastrointestinal (UGI) source or profound thrombocytopenia. He is receiving transfusions and correction of coagulopathy.
8. Renal failure: The patient has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is no longer receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is multifactorial and is being monitored.
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient is receiving insulin infusion and is being monitored for glucose levels.
11. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia attributed to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT+) and medications (meropenem, pentoprozol). He is receiving transfusions and correction of coagulopathy.
12. HIT+: The patient is being avoided of heparin.
13. LFT abnormalities: The patient has liver function test (LFT) abnormalities consistent with shock liver, which are slowly resolving.

The patient's disposition is DNR (do not resuscitate), and he is currently in the ICU. His family is considering long-term options, including tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG).

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infiltrates, complicated
   by multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).
   Gradual signs of clinical improvement.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).   Now multifactorial
   (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, underlying COPD).  Now
   evidence for new VAP (RLL infiltrate).  Continue steroids --> taper,
   continue antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider
   tracheostomy if no contined progress, family considering long-term
   option.  Consult IP service for trach/PEG.
   MOTOR WEAKNESS, GENERALIZED -- attributed to ICU neuropathy (attributed
   to steroids and paralytic use).  Anticipate gradual recovery.
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  A-line d/c'd.  Plan continue antimicrobials to
   full course.
   FEVER -- Attributed in part to bacteremia.  Monitor temperature.
   HYPOTENSION --  Currently improved.  Monitor BP, maintain MAP > 60
   mmHg.
   CAD -- recent evidence for myocardial damage --> possible demand
   ischemia.  Now stable.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of profound thrombocytopenia.  Maintain
   venous access, serial Hct, transfuse.  Transfuse plts, correct
   coagulopathy, dDAVP.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN.  Now off CVVH since yesterday.
   Monitor intrinsic renal function.
   ANEMIA -- multifactorial.  Now evidence for blood loss, GI source.
   Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 28.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose
   <150.

   (meropenem, pentoprozol).  [**Month (only) 51**] be attributed to active GI bleed
   (consumption).  Monitor.   Hematology consultation in progress.
   HIT+ -- avoid heparin.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 tolerating TF.  D/C TPN.
   LFT ABNORMALITIES -- consistent with shock liver.  Continues to resolve
   slowly.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male who is critically ill and has been in the ICU for an extended period. The patient has a complex medical history, including respiratory failure, multisystem organ failure, and various underlying conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and congestive heart failure (CHF).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a recent development of a new ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in the right lower lobe.
* Motor weakness: The patient has generalized motor weakness attributed to ICU neuropathy, which is expected to improve gradually.
* Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for Gram-positive cocci (GPC) likely related to a central line.
* Fever: The patient's fever is attributed in part to the bacteremia and is being monitored.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has improved, but it is still being monitored to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.
* CAD: The patient has recent evidence of myocardial damage, which may be related to demand ischemia.
* Melena/hematochezia: The patient has bleeding from an unknown source, which may be related to a gastrointestinal source (peptic ulcer disease or gastritis) or a coagulopathy.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is no longer receiving continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Anemia: The patient has a multifactorial anemia, including blood loss and a gastrointestinal source.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are being monitored and managed with insulin infusion.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count below 50,000, which is attributed to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT+) and medications.

The patient's medications include:

* Antibiotics: Meropenem, cefipime, and vancomycin
* Sedatives: Midazolam and fentanyl
* Pain management: None mentioned
* Anticoagulation: None
* Proton pump inhibitors (PPI): For stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin: Avoided due to HIT+

The patient's nutrition is being managed with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and fiber repletion.

The patient's disposition is currently DNR (do not resuscitate), and the family is considering long-term care options, including tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further respiratory failure and VAP
* Sepsis and septic shock
* Cardiac arrhythmias and ischemia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation
* Renal failure and electrolyte imbalances
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis
* Nutritional deficiencies and malnutrition

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]):
   Differential of initial failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated
   vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung
   disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to
   be consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are
   negative on repeat here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process
   is multifactorial: pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD
   with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology. Current barriers to
   extubation are CHF, muscular weakness, and underlying poor reserves.
   - cont PSV trial daily
   - IP deferring trach until platelets consistently greater than 50
   - now off steroids
   - Keep at least -1L per day
   - Continue to treat? VAP
   .
   >. FEVER/UTI: Currently afebrile CXR this AM shows RLL infiltrate more
   concerning  for infection. Respiratory status unchanged, no increase
   secretions. Prior sputum has grown pan-[**Last Name (un) 270**] Klebsiella but has been
   hospitalized and intubated >3 weeks so high risk of resistant
   organisms.
   Also UA c/w infection, changed Foley and started vanco/cefepime for
   UTI. Line infection is also a concern, will monitor blood cx and D/C
   fem HD cath after HD tomorrow.
   - f/u cx
   - add cipro for pseudomonas double coverage
   - cont vanco/cefepime, renally dosed
   .
   >. Pancytopenia
 Stopped meropenem which can cause pancytopenia, would
   continue to trend. Heme/onc thought drug-related although unclear why
   plts so low. HIT + but SRA pending. Smear unremarkable. Alternative
   explanation is that patient had baseline leucopenia prior to high dose
   steroids, and we are now seeing this return to baseline.
   - appreciate heme/onc recs
   - switch pantoprazole to ranitidine
   - send HIT + and serotonin assay
 pending
   - send SPEP, UPEP
   - Would hold off on anti-coagulation at least until SRA returns
   - consider BM bx
   - transfuse for Hct>28, Plt>10 unless bleeding
   - check [**Hospital1 7**] CBC
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Off CVVH
   - Plan for HD tuesday
   .
   >  GI BLEED
 Likely lower GIB, unclear source and patient never
   bleeding enough to scope. Now improved with only oozing when rectum
   cleaned. Also having oral mucosal bleeding, with friable mucosa.
   - send HSV and CMV
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving Likely [**2-10**] poor
   hepatic clearance of sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic
   encephalopathy.  MRI showedrior right MCA infarct, nothing acute.
   Patient now improving towards baseline, interactive and appropriate.
   - trial off CVVH, BUN increasing and will have HD tomorrow
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver. Repeat TTE showed biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 28
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
   #. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS: Pt has LFTs c/w ischemic injury, now trending
   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Will readdress question of trach/PEG.
   ..
   FEN: TF
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboot
   - raniditine
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC, fem HD line
   .
   CODE STATUS:  DNR
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .
   DISPOSITION:  [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] pending above
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who presented to the hospital with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, systolic heart failure, and altered mental status. He has a history of chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for several weeks and has developed various complications, including respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, gastrointestinal bleeding, and pancytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 100 mmHg. He is still dependent on mechanical ventilation and has a risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's kidney function is deteriorating, with a creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 32 mg/dL. He is at risk of developing end-stage renal disease (ESRD) if not treated promptly.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has had multiple episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding, which has led to anemia and the need for blood transfusions. He is at risk of developing further bleeding complications.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which increases his risk of bleeding complications. He is also at risk of developing infections due to his neutropenia.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of systolic heart failure and has developed worsening ischemia laterally in the I and aVL leads, which may indicate a demand ischemia. He is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has developed weakness and altered mental status, which may be due to his prolonged ICU stay, steroids, and other medications. He is at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as delirium or seizures.
7. Infections: The patient has developed a bloodstream infection with CoNS and is at risk of developing further infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's plan of care should focus on addressing his respiratory, cardiac, and gastrointestinal complications. He should be continued on mechanical ventilation and receive treatment for his VAP. His kidney function should be closely monitored, and he should receive treatment for his acute kidney injury. His gastrointestinal bleeding should be managed with blood transfusions and medications to reduce the risk of further bleeding. His pancytopenia should be managed with blood transfusions and medications to reduce the risk of bleeding complications. His cardiac complications should be managed with medications to reduce the risk of further ischemia. His neurological complications should be managed with medications to reduce the risk of further neurological damage. Finally, his infections should be managed with antibiotics and other medications to reduce the risk of further complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with systolic heart failure, acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP). The patient has a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and type II diabetes. He has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and steroids.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains on mechanical ventilation and has a history of BOOP and acute on chronic kidney injury.
2. Pancytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he has been treated with platelet transfusions.
3. Renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
4. GI bleed: The patient has had a lower gastrointestinal bleed and is being treated with anticoagulants and transfusions.
5. Fever and UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection and is being treated with antibiotics.
6. Altered mental status: The patient has had altered mental status and is being treated with sedatives and anticonvulsants.
7. Hypotension: The patient has had hypotension and is being treated with vasopressors.
8. Coronary artery disease: The patient has evidence of worsening ischemia and is being treated with anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his urinary tract infection and pneumonia.
2. ARDS: The patient is at risk for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to his respiratory failure and pneumonia.
3. Renal failure: The patient is at risk for further renal failure due to his pre-existing chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury.
4. GI bleed: The patient is at risk for further GI bleed due to his pre-existing GI disease and anticoagulant therapy.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his urinary catheter and central venous catheter.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient is at risk for cardiac complications due to his coronary artery disease and heart failure.
7. Neurological complications: The patient is at risk for neurological complications due to his altered mental status and history of stroke.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and management. The plan includes:

1. Continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Antibiotic therapy for the urinary tract infection and pneumonia.
3. Anticoagulant therapy to prevent further thrombosis.
4. Transfusion therapy to support the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia.
5. Renal replacement therapy to support the patient's acute kidney injury.
6. GI bleed management to prevent further bleeding.
7. Infection prevention and control measures to prevent further infection.
8. Cardiac management to prevent further cardiac complications.
9. Neurological management to prevent further neurological complications.

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to his complex medical condition and multiple organ dysfunction.

   (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, underlying COPD).
   Evidence for VAP (RLL infiltrate).  Continue steroids --> taper,
   continue antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider
   tracheostomy if no contined progress, family considering long-term

   intrinsic renal function.
   LEFT ARM SWELLING -- concern for thrombus --> NIVS
   ANEMIA -- multifactorial.  Now evidence for blood loss, GI source.
   Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 28.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose
   <150.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- attributed to HIT+ and in part to mediations
   (meropenem, pentoprozol).  [**Month (only) 51**] also be attributed to active GI bleed
   (consumption).  Monitor.   Hematology consultation following.
   HIT+ -- avoid heparin products.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 tolerating TF.  D/C TPN.
   LFT ABNORMALITIES -- consistent with shock liver.  Continues to resolve
   slowly.
   DISPOSITION -- DNR currently.  Maintain discussions with family.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient, an 83-year-old male, is critically ill with respiratory failure, multisystem organ failure, and chronic underlying conditions such as coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic heart failure (CHF), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and has undergone various interventions, including antibiotic therapy, steroids, and mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has shown gradual signs of improvement, but the patient remains critically ill.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, and underlying COPD. The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and the possibility of tracheostomy is being considered.
2. **Bacteremia:** The patient has a positive blood culture for GPC, likely related to a line infection. The patient is being treated with antimicrobials, and the line has been discontinued.
3. **CAD:** The patient has evidence of recent myocardial damage, which is now stable.
4. **Melena/Hematochezia:** The patient has an unclear source of bleeding, which may be related to a gastrointestinal source (PUD, gastritis) in the context of profound thrombocytopenia.
5. **Renal Failure:** The patient has undergone acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is currently off continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
6. **Left Arm Swelling:** The patient has concern for thrombus formation in the left arm, which is being monitored.
7. **Anemia:** The patient has multifactorial anemia, including blood loss and gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. **Hyperglycemia:** The patient has hyperglycemia, which is being managed with insulin infusion and monitoring.
9. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is attributed to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT+) and medications (meropenem, pentoprozol). The patient's platelet count is being monitored, and hematology consultation is being considered.
10. **Nutritional Support:** The patient is tolerating tube feeds (TF) and has discontinued total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

Overall, the patient remains critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of multiple medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, diffuse infiltrates, and multisystem organ failure. The patient's condition is complicated by cardiac ischemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and underlying coronary artery disease (CAD).

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.7°F)
* Heart rate: 114 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 159/71 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 36 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic, no poor dentition, no NG tube, no OG tube
* Lymphatic: Cervical WNL (within normal limits), no supraclavicular WNL, no cervical adenopathy
* Cardiovascular: PMI (point of maximal impulse) normal, no hyperdynamic, S1 and S2 normal, no rub
* Peripheral vascular: Right and left radial pulses present, right and left digital pulses present
* Respiratory/chest: Symmetric expansion, resonant percussion, clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema 1+, no cyanosis, no clubbing
* Skin: Warm, no rash, no jaundice
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, no oriented, no sedated, no paralyzed, tone normal

Laboratory results reveal:

* Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 24 K/uL
* Platelet count: 41
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.69 ng/mL
* Glucose: 145 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.7 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* D-dimer: 12853 ng/mL
* Fibrinogen: 273 mg/dL
* Lactate dehydrogenase: 380 IU/L

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: Continue steroids, antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation. Consider tracheostomy if no continued progress.
* Motor weakness: Anticipate gradual recovery.
* Bacteremia: Continue antimicrobials to full course.
* CAD: Evidence for recent myocardial damage, now stable.
* Melena/haematemesis: Unclear source, but concerns include UGI source (PUD, gastritis) in context of profound thrombocytopenia.
* Renal failure: S/p ATN, now remains off CVVH. Continue to monitor intrinsic renal function.
* Left arm swelling: Concern for thrombus, NIVS.
* Anemia: Multifactorial, now evidence for blood loss, GI source. Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 28.
* Hyperglycemia: Insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose <150.
* Thrombocytopenia: Attributed to HIT+ and in part to medications (meropenem, pentoprozol). Monitor, hematology consultation following.
* HIT+: Avoid heparin products.
* Nutritional support: Tolerating TF, d/c TPN.
* LFT abnormalities: Consistent with shock liver, continues to resolve slowly.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and respiratory muscle weakness.
* Bacteremia: Sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.
* CAD: Myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, and heart failure.
* Melena/haematemesis: Gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, and hypovolemic shock.
* Renal failure: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Thrombocytopenia: Bleeding, petechiae, and ecchymoses.
* Hyperglycemia: Diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar non-ketotic hyperglycemia, and hypoglycemia.
* Anemia: Fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]):
   Differential of initial failure includes CHF, VAP, and obstructive lung
   disease (noted on CT chest from OSH) possibly with another unknown
   primary problem causing initial hemoptysis.  Patients last PFTs mild to
   moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA, anti-GBM
   negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows
   clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is
   multifactorial: pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD with
   ground glass opacities of unknown etiology. Current barriers to
   extubation are CHF, muscular weakness, and underlying poor reserves.
   - cont PSV trial daily
   - IP deferring trach until platelets consistently greater than 50
   - now off steroids
   - Keep at least -1L per day
   - Continue to treat? VAP with vanco/cipro/cefepime
   .
   >.
 DEEP VENOUS THROMBOSIS (DVT), LOWER EXTREMITY- HIT Ab positive
   with RLE DVT. Started argatroban.
   - send SRA 24 hrs after starting argatroban, f/u sent SRA
   - argatroban with goal PTT 60-80
   - monitor platelets for recovery
   .
   >. FEVER: Currently afebrile CXR showed RLL infiltrate concerning  for
   infection. +UA but neg urine cx. Respiratory status unchanged, no
   increase secretions. Prior sputum has grown pan-[**Last Name (un) 270**] Klebsiella but has
   been hospitalized and intubated >3 weeks so high risk of resistant
   organisms. D/Ced fem HD cath. Blood cx all neg.
   - f/u cx
   - cont vanco/cefepime/cipro, renally dosed
   .
   >. Pancytopenia
 Stopped meropenem which can cause pancytopenia. Smear
   unremarkable. HIT positive, SRA pending, +RLE DVT. WBC now trending up
   while platelets continue to be 20s.
   - appreciate heme/onc recs
   - f/u SPEP, UPEP
   - transfuse for Hct>28, Plt>10 unless bleeding

   .

   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. s/p CVVH. BUN/Cr now
   trending up.

   - discuss plan for HD
   .

 Likely lower GIB, unclear source and patient never
   bleeding enough to scope. Now improved with only oozing when rectum
   cleaned. Also having oral mucosal bleeding, with friable mucosa.
   - f/u HSV and CMV
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   .

   clearance of sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic
   encephalopathy.  MRI showedrior right MCA infarct, nothing acute.
   Patient now improving towards baseline, interactive and appropriate.
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver. Repeat TTE showed biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.

 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line

   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far

 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the ICU for acute hypoxic respiratory failure with evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient has a history of systolic heart failure, and the current respiratory failure is multifactorial, involving pulmonary hematoma, congestive heart failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

The patient has a number of ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower extremity, which has been treated with argatroban.
2. Pancytopenia, which has been attributed to meropenem and is being monitored with serial complete blood counts (CBCs).
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI), which has been treated with continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
4. GI bleeding, which has been treated with transfusions and is being monitored for signs of bleeding.
5. Altered mental status, which is likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy and is being treated with sedation and analgesia.
6. Hypotension, which has been treated with vasopressors and is being monitored for signs of shock.
7. Coronary artery disease (CAD), which is being treated with medication and is being monitored for signs of worsening ischemia.
8. Biventricular systolic heart failure, which is being treated with medication and is being monitored for signs of worsening heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's biventricular systolic heart failure is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's AKI is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.
6. DVT: The patient's DVT is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.
7. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.
8. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is a significant concern and may worsen if not properly managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac failure with medication and monitor for signs of worsening heart failure.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust therapy as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's GI bleeding with transfusions and monitor for signs of bleeding.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's DVT and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's altered mental status and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider the patient's code status and discuss with the patient's family and healthcare team.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with systolic heart failure, acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient has a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, and a history of COPD.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure, acute, hypoxic (not ARDS)
2. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), lower extremity, with positive heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) antibodies
3. Renal failure, acute (ARF)
4. GI bleed, likely lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleed
5. Altered mental status, likely due to poor hepatic clearance of sedatives and uremia
6. Hypotension, resolved
7. Weakeness, likely due to steroids, paralysis, and prolonged ICU course
8. Bacteremia, with CoNS (coagulase-negative staphylococcus) growing in blood cultures
9. Coronary artery disease (CAD), with evidence of worsening ischemia and troponin elevation
10. Biventricular systolic heart failure, likely due to CAD
11. Ischemic hepatitis, with LFTs c/w ischemic injury
12. Diabetes mellitus, type II

The patient's current medications include:

1. Argatroban for DVT treatment
2. Cefepime, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin for VAP treatment
3. Lasix for fluid management
4. Steroids, stopped due to pancytopenia
5. Insulin drip for diabetes management

The patient's goals of care include:

1. Tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) pending bleeding and anticoagulation issues
2. DVT prophylaxis with argatroban
3. Bowel regimen
4. Pain management
5. Continued ICU care

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and their emergency contact is listed as [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF)**], and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**].

The patient's disposition is pending, with a possible transfer to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infiltrates, complicated
   by multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).
   Gradual signs of clinical improvement.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).   Now multifactorial
   (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, underlying COPD).
   Evidence for VAP (RLL infiltrate).  Continue steroids --> taper,
   continue antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider
   tracheostomy if no contined progress, family considering long-term
   option.  Consult IP service for trach/PEG.  Consider repeat
   bronchoscopy.
   MOTOR WEAKNESS, GENERALIZED -- attributed to ICU neuropathy (attributed
   to steroids and paralytic use).  Anticipate gradual recovery.
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  A-line d/c'd.  Plan continue antimicrobials to
   full course.
   DVT -- right femoral --> argatroban now started.  Aim for PTT 60-80.
   CAD --  evidence for recent myocardial damage --> Now stable.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of profound thrombocytopenia.  Maintain
   venous access, serial Hct, transfuse.  Transfuse plts, correct
   coagulopathy, dDAVP.
   RENAL FAILURE -- s/p ATN.  Now remains off CVVH.  Continue to monitor
   intrinsic renal function.
   LEFT ARM SWELLING -- concern for thrombus --> NIVS
   ANEMIA -- multifactorial.  Now evidence for blood loss, GI source.
   Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 28.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose
   <150.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- attributed to HIT+ and in part to mediations
   (meropenem, pentoprozol).  [**Month (only) 51**] also be attributed to active GI bleed
   (consumption).  Monitor.   Hematology consultation following.
   HIT+ -- avoid heparin products.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 tolerating TF.  D/C TPN.
   LFT ABNORMALITIES -- consistent with shock liver.  Continues to resolve
   slowly.
   DISPOSITION -- DNR currently.  Maintain discussions with family.
